Legal_Issue: Did the Board misinterpret s. 2(3) of the Immigration Act and fail to apply it properly?
Outcome: The application is allowed, and the matter is returned for redetermination by a new panel due to the Board's legal error.
Basis_of_Claim: Mr. Jiminez claimed refugee status based on past persecution in El Salvador, but the Board rejected his claim.
Application_Error: Focused on current psychological state post-brain injury rather than nature of past persecution
Evidence_Ignored: Severity and appalling nature of past torture in El Salvador
Legal_Standard: Whether the Board correctly applied s. 2(3)
Application_Factor: Compelling reasons arising from past persecution

Procedural_Fairness_Issue: Board failed to consider severity of past persecution
Decision_Outcome: Remanded for reconsideration by a newly constituted panel
Evidence_Source: Testimony of Mr. Jiminez regarding torture
Basis_for_Decision: Severe torture suffered in the past
Procedural_Fairness_Breach: Failure to assess compelling reasons under s. 2(3)

Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 2(3) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Application_Facts: Applicant endured detention, physical and sexual abuse, loss of family members due to military actions, ongoing psychological trauma
Procedural_Issue: Board's failure to properly assess persecution; case remanded to a differently constituted panel
Evidence_Used: Testimony of applicant, psychological evidence of trauma
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Board did not adequately consider evidence of past persecution and subjective fear
Credibility_Assessment: Applicant's experiences deemed credible and supported by psychological evidence
Decision_Outcome: Board denied claim based on lack of previous persecution
Outcome: Judicial review granted; decision set aside
Legal_Standard_Applied: Definition of persecution including serious harassment and ill-treatment; standard under Section 2(3) for serious past persecution
Decision_Rationale: Board erred in law by failing to recognize the applicant's experiences as persecution; acts described were atrocious and appalling
Authority_Responsible: Refugee Division of the Immigration and Refugee Board

Violation_Type: Failure to meet refugee status criteria
Application_Facts: Applicant was tortured by MQM in 1989
Continuing psychological effects from past persecution
Misrepresentation_Element: Board expressed doubts about applicant's credibility
Procedural_Issue: Board incorrectly required ongoing fear of persecution
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Credibility concerns affecting weight of evidence
Credibility_Assessment: Board doubted applicant's credibility but acknowledged severe past persecution
Remedy_Sought: Remand for new hearing with differently constituted tribunal
Legal_Standard_Applied: High threshold under s. 2(3) of the Immigration Act for past persecution
Decision_Rationale: Error in requiring ongoing fear of persecution
Need to reassess whether s. 2(3) threshold is met

Application_Facts: Applicants claimed Convention refugee status based on past persecution in Chile; Tribunal accepted credible evidence of past persecution but dismissed claim due to changed country conditions without addressing s. 2(3)
Procedural_Issue: Tribunal failed to consider s. 2(3) despite evidence of past persecution
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failure to assess compelling reasons arising from past persecution under s. 2(3)
Credibility_Assessment: The applicant's evidence was found credible
Decision_Outcome: Claim dismissed based on changed country conditions
Legal_Standard_Applied: Interpretation of s. 2(3) of the Immigration Act regarding continued refugee status despite changed country conditions
Decision_Rationale: The Tribunal erred in law by not considering s. 2(3) which requires assessment of compelling reasons arising from past persecution

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to Provide Protection under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant is a victim of abuse by a high-ranking official in Mexico; faces challenges accessing state protection due to abuser's status
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Board failed to properly assess internal flight alternative (IFA) and personal circumstances
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Assessment of state protection within Mexico
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Testimony regarding abuse and lack of police response
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Board did not address specific barriers to accessing protection
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Not challenged on credibility grounds
Crimes.Outcome: Set aside and remitted for redetermination
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Judicial review and reassessment by the Board
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Board failed to rebut presumption of state protection with clear evidence and neglected personal circumstances in IFA analysis

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Refugee protection claim based on persecution
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Adequacy of state protection and viability of internal flight alternative
Crimes.Governing_Law: IRPA, Ward framework, IFA two-step test
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Applicant’s testimony on abuse and systemic corruption
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On claimant to show lack of effective state protection
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Two-step IFA test must consider personal circumstances
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Fear of persecution due to domestic violence by state actor
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Abuser’s high-ranking status, lack of police intervention
Crimes.Defendant_Response: State protection presumed but not demonstrated as effective

Crimes.Aggravating_Factors: Perpetrator’s position of power and influence
Crimes.Risk_Assessment: Ongoing risk of harm if returned
Crimes.Threat_Source: Former intimate partner with state authority
Crimes.Targeted_Victimization: Yes, due to relationship with perpetrator
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Not questioned

Crimes.Aggravating_Factors: Official status of perpetrator enabling impunity
Crimes.Prior_Criminality: History of abuse and unlawful confinement
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Consistent and plausible account

Legal_Issue: Whether the Board erred in determining no nexus to Convention refugee grounds and availability of effective state protection
Outcome: Application for judicial review allowed; matter remitted for re-determination by a new Board
Application_Error: Unreasonable conclusions on nexus and state protection

Crime_Name: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act Violation
Legal_Provision_Violated: Assessment of cumulative persecution in PRRA under IRPA
Application_Facts: Officer acknowledged individual risks but failed to assess them cumulatively in the PRRA decision, unlike in the H&C decision
Claimant_Status: Applicant claiming refugee protection, denied; subsequent H&C and PRRA applications rejected
Procedural_Issue: Failure to consider cumulative persecution in PRRA assessment, raising procedural fairness concerns
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Omission of cumulative risk analysis despite existence of multiple discriminatory acts
Decision_Outcome: PRRA and H&C decisions set aside; judicial review allowed
Outcome: Remitted for redetermination by a different officer
Remedy_Sought: Redetermination of PRRA and H&C applications
Legal_Standard_Applied: Officers must assess risks cumulatively if multiple discriminatory acts exist under IRPA
Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness for factual findings; correctness for procedural fairness
Decision_Rationale: Failure to assess cumulative persecution could have affected the outcome of the PRRA decision
Authority_Responsible: Immigration officer responsible for PRRA and H&C decisions

Application_Facts: Kincolith Band used Marlon Watts' land without permission from 1985 for communication equipment; trespass continued past 1996 statement of claim
Procedural_Issue: Default judgment granted in 1999 due to non-contestation; damages determined via reference hearing
Decision_Outcome: Damages limited to period before statement of claim (1985–1996); future claims require new action
Outcome: Plaintiff awarded $10,300 in damages, $5,281.95 in costs, and interest
Relief_Sought: Damages for unauthorized use of land
Legal_Standard_Applied: Under common law, damages only for losses accrued before commencement of action
Decision_Rationale: Continuing damages not allowed beyond date of statement of claim without specific rules permitting otherwise
Authority_Responsible: Court granting default judgment and determining damages

Application_Facts: Applicant claims PRRA officer ignored relevant evidence about Sri Lanka's conditions; officer relied on general improvements in Sri Lanka’s conditions
Procedural_Issue: Selective use of country reports and omission of contrary evidence alleged
Evidence_Used: Country reports used selectively by PRRA officer
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Omission of evidence contrary to the officer's conclusions
Relief_Sought: Successful PRRA application, reversal of removal risk assessment
Decision_Rationale: Officer's decision did not significantly misrepresent risk; cited evidence does not alter core claim of risk upon return

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether Sean Eren's actions constitute contempt of court for failing to comply with the Anton Piller Order
Crimes.Governing_Law: Rules 466 to 472 of the Federal Courts Rules
Crimes.Procedural_Stage: Post-grant review of Anton Piller Order and show cause proceedings
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Sean Eren concealed his computer and hard drive, failed to preserve data, and allowed erasure or corruption despite court order
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Show cause order issued for potential contempt
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Defendant's failure to produce electronic evidence raised suspicion of spoliation
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Prima facie case required for contempt; show cause order issued if satisfied
Crimes.Standard_of_Review: Strict compliance with court orders required
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Non-compliance with Anton Piller Order including concealment and destruction of evidence
Crimes.Outcome_on_Merits: Contempt allegation not yet adjudicated; show cause order issued
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Concealment of computer and hard drive, loss of data
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Federal Court procedural rules on interim remedies and enforcement
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Failure to disclose and preserve digital materials as required
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Enforcement of Anton Piller Order, sanctions for non-compliance
Crimes.Outcome: Show cause order issued against Sean Eren

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Intellectual Property and Confidential Information Dispute

Crimes.Legal_Rule: Federal Court lacks jurisdiction over pure breach of confidence claims
Crimes.Standard_of_Review: Judicial review of ex parte injunctions
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged misuse of confidential information by former employee
Crimes.Outcome_on_Merits: Claim dismissed due to lack of jurisdiction and weak evidence
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Nature of confidential information, employment relationship, access logs
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Equitable doctrine of breach of confidence
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Challenged validity and scope of Anton Piller Order
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Employment records, data access logs, internal communications
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Common law principles; Federal Courts Act

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether Netbored Inc. had a strong prima facie case of copyright infringement

Crimes.Standard_of_Review: Judicial scrutiny of ex parte emergency relief

Crimes.Defendant_Response: Denied substantial copying and challenged necessity of order
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Digital content, source code, expert analysis

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Validity of Anton Piller Order based on misrepresentation in ex parte application

Crimes.Outcome: Anton Piller Order vacated due to inadequate disclosure

Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Lack of transparency and speculative nature of damages
Crimes.Proceeding_Type: Ex parte application followed by inter partes review
Crimes.Application_Error: Failure to meet threshold requirements for Anton Piller relief
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Extremely strong prima facie case standard
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Contradictory evidence downplayed in initial application
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Good faith and completeness in urgent equitable relief applications
Crimes.Application_Factor: Incomplete factual basis presented to court
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Order vacated, interim injunction set aside
Crimes.Standard_of_Review: Abuse of process and equitable discretion
Crimes.Document_Fraud: No direct fraud found, but material omissions noted

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the immigration officer erred in finding the applicant inadmissible due to membership in a terrorist organization
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Insufficient reasoning and questionable reliability of evidence
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On the officer to demonstrate inadmissibility
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Reliability of sources and lack of specific findings
Crimes.Legal_Rule: A foreign national is inadmissible if they are a member of an organization reasonably believed to engage in terrorism

Crimes.Outcome_on_Merits: Remanded for reconsideration by a different officer
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Evidence regarding MQM-A's alleged terrorist activities
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Applicant challenged procedural fairness and evidentiary basis

Crimes.National_Security_Danger: Alleged involvement with MQM-A, an organization suspected of terrorism
Crimes.Threat_Assessment: Membership in a group allegedly engaged in terrorist acts
Crimes.Risk_Factor: Affiliation with a designated or suspected terrorist organization
Crimes.Nature_of_Acts: Engagement in or support of terrorism
Crimes.Admission_or_Involvement: Alleged membership in a terrorist organization
Crimes.Evidence_Credibility: Low; based on vague and unreliable sources
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Issue: Lack of credible, specific, and verifiable evidence
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Officer failed to properly assess credibility
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Immigration inadmissibility based on security grounds

Application_Facts: Applicants claimed Officer failed to consider establishment, best interests of children, and procedural fairness; however, evidence showed these were considered but weighed against other factors.
Procedural_Issue: Concerns regarding procedural fairness in the assessment of humanitarian and compassionate (H&C) grounds
Evidence_Used: Officer's assessment including consideration of establishment, best interests of children, and procedural fairness
Outcome: Application for judicial review dismissed; no reviewable error found
Relief_Sought: Permanent residence on humanitarian and compassionate grounds
Legal_Standard_Applied: Best interests of the child, procedural fairness under IRPA
Decision_Rationale: Officer properly considered relevant factors including establishment and best interests of children, and no reviewable error was identified in weighing those against other considerations

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Visa refusal based on credibility and admissibility

Application_Facts: The applicants' claim was denied due to credibility issues.
Procedural_Issue: The RAD improperly applied a judicial review standard instead of conducting a proper appeal.
Credibility_Assessment: Credibility issues led to denial of the refugee claim.
Decision_Outcome: RPD's denial of refugee status upheld by RAD initially, then set aside on judicial review.
Outcome: Judicial review allowed; case remanded to RAD for redetermination.
Relief_Sought: Challenge to the legality of the RAD decision upholding the RPD's denial.
Remedy_Sought: Reconsideration of the case by the RAD under correct legal standards.
Standard_of_Review: The RAD must conduct an appeal, not a judicial review, applying the correct legal standards.
Decision_Rationale: The RAD failed to conduct a proper appeal and incorrectly applied a judicial review standard.

Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 96 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Application_Facts: Paramsothy claimed refugee status based on alleged persecution in Sri Lanka
Procedural_Issue: RPD applied incorrect standard of proof ('balance of probabilities' instead of 'serious possibility')
Evidence_Used: Evidence submitted by Paramsothy regarding persecution in Sri Lanka
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient evidence cited by RPD due to incorrect legal standard
Remedy_Sought: Redetermination of refugee claim by a different RPD panel
Legal_Standard_Applied: Balance of probabilities (incorrectly); correct standard is 'serious possibility')
Standard_of_Review: Serious possibility of persecution under Section 96
Decision_Rationale: RPD used a higher burden of proof than required, leading to legal error

Crime_Name: Failure to comply with immigration release conditions
Violation_Type: Breach of reporting, curfew, and document production conditions
Application_Facts: Mr. Khalife failed to report, broke curfew, and did not produce required documents; representations were made by counsel but not all mitigating factors were considered
Procedural_Issue: Manager did not explicitly explain how the $50,000 amount was determined
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of explicit reasoning on proportionality of forfeiture amount
Remedy_Sought: Return of deposit or reduction in forfeiture amount
Decision_Rationale: Breaches occurred; decision maker considered submissions; overall decision fell within a reasonable range despite lack of detailed explanation on amount

Violation_Type: Breach of curfew, reporting, and carrying required documents
Application_Facts: Mr. Khalife breached multiple release conditions; manager acknowledged awareness of conditions but did not fully consider partial compliance or lack of flight risk
Procedural_Issue: Failure to explicitly address proportionality and mitigating factors in decision
Evidence_Used: Documentation of missed check-ins, curfew violations, non-production of documents
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient explanation regarding proportionality of $50,000 forfeiture
Decision_Rationale: Breach established; discretion exercised within legal framework; court deferred to administrative decision despite proportionality concerns

Crimes.Application_Factor: Initial non-disclosure leading to exclusion under s. 117(9)(d)

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to disclose family members in immigration application

Dispute_Type: Civil dispute over intellectual property rights
Legal_Issue: Whether Euro Excellence is liable for damages and profits due to copyright infringement of Kraft Canada's artistic works on chocolate bar wrappers
Procedural_Stage: Initial trial, appeal, remand for redetermination of damages, motions regarding new evidence, final determination
Evidence_Assessment: Gross sales of $2.8 million; lack of cost evidence from Euro Excellence; Kraft's proposed 10-25% of gross sales as reasonable
Decision_Outcome: Euro Excellence must pay $300,000 in damages plus interest and one set of costs
Burden_of_Proof: On Kraft Canada to establish infringement and quantify damages/profits
Credibility_Factor: Court found Kraft's proposed range reasonable despite lack of precise evidence
Legal_Rule: Under Section 35(1) of the Copyright Act, infringer is liable for owner's damages and portion of profits not accounted for in damages
Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness of damages assessment on remand
Grounds_for_Claim: Unauthorized sale of products with copyrighted chocolate bar wrappers
Key_Evidence_Considered: Gross sales figures, absence of cost documentation from defendant, plaintiff's profit margin proposal
Legal_Framework: Canadian Copyright Act, civil litigation procedures
Defendant_Response: Did not provide evidence of costs incurred
Evidence_Type: Financial records, expert or industry practice on profit margins
Outcome: $300,000 in damages, interest, and one set of costs awarded to Kraft Canada
Authority: Federal Court of Appeal, Federal Court

Evidence_Sufficiency: Insufficient evidence to support gang membership
Evidence_Credibility: Did not meet police criteria for gang membership
Legal_Provision: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, s. 37(1)(a)

Dispute_Type: Immigration inadmissibility based on alleged criminal organization membership
Legal_Issue: Whether the Board erred in concluding gang membership
Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, s. 37(1)(a)
Evidence_Assessment: Reliance on police reports and testimony deemed insufficient
Credibility_Factor: Hearsay evidence not meeting police criteria for gang membership
Key_Evidence_Considered: Police reports linking individual to gang-related activities
Legal_Provision: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, s. 37(1)(a)

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to comply with a recognizance
Dispute_Type: Immigration inadmissibility due to alleged gang affiliation
Legal_Issue: Whether reasonable grounds existed to believe gang membership
Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, s. 37(1)(a)
Evidence_Assessment: Evidence lacked specifics proving active involvement
Credibility_Factor: Reliance on allegations and hearsay without corroboration
Legal_Rule: Membership determination requires credible and trustworthy evidence
Grounds_for_Claim: Lack of concrete evidence of gang membership
Legal_Provision: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, s. 37(1)(a)

Dispute_Type: Immigration inadmissibility over alleged criminal organization ties
Legal_Issue: Sufficiency of evidence for reasonable belief in gang membership
Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, s. 37(1)(a)
Evidence_Assessment: Criminal record lacked direct evidence of gang involvement
Credibility_Factor: Evidence based on association and history, not direct participation
Legal_Rule: Standard allows hearsay but requires credibility
Grounds_for_Claim: Insufficient evidence of actual gang membership
Key_Evidence_Considered: Police reports and testimony on gang links
Legal_Provision: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, s. 37(1)(a)

Crimes.Crime_Name: Reasonable grounds belief in membership of criminal organization
Dispute_Type: Alleged membership in Tamil gang leading to deportation
Legal_Issue: Whether Board applied 'reasonable grounds' standard correctly
Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, s. 37(1)(a)
Evidence_Assessment: Police evidence did not meet internal criteria for gang membership
Credibility_Factor: Reliance on indirect associations and unverified reports
Legal_Rule: Person inadmissible if member of organization engaged in planned criminal activity
Grounds_for_Claim: Lack of sufficient and credible evidence
Key_Evidence_Considered: Links to gang-related activities without formal membership
Legal_Provision: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, s. 37(1)(a)

Violation_Type: Inadmissibility due to alleged criminal organization membership
Legal_Provision_Violated: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, s. 37(1)(a)
Application_Facts: Accused based on associations and past incidents
Evidence_Used: Police reports and testimony linking to gang activities
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Did not meet police criteria for gang membership
Decision_Rationale: Lack of credible evidence supporting active gang membership

Violation_Type: Failure to establish proper nexus to a Convention ground
Legal_Provision_Violated: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA) subsection 96, 97
Governing_Law: Convention Relating to the Status of Refugees
Application_Facts: Sri Lankan Tamil individual fled persecution; associated with passengers aboard MV Sun Sea; claimed fear of persecution based on ethnicity and association
Procedural_Issue: Standard of review for mixed questions of law and fact
Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal Court's jurisdiction under IRPA subsection 72(1) for judicial review
Evidence_Used: RPD findings on Tamil ethnicity and association with MV Sun Sea passengers
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Deficiencies in linking association with MV Sun Sea to Convention grounds
Decision_Outcome: RPD granted refugee status based on nexus to Convention ground of race (Tamil ethnicity)
Outcome: Application for judicial review dismissed; RPD decision upheld
Remedy_Sought: Overturning of RPD's refugee status determination
Legal_Standard_Applied: Nexus between fear of persecution and a Convention ground
Decision_Rationale: RPD's finding of nexus based on race (Tamil ethnicity) was reasonable; deficiencies in other factors did not undermine the overall decision

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the Minister's Delegate reasonably concluded that the Applicant would not be at risk if returned to Pakistan
Crimes.Outcome: Judicial review granted, decision set aside, matter remitted for redetermination
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant claimed risk of torture due to inclusion on CBSA's wanted list
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence on human rights conditions in Pakistan, reports of torture in detention
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Risk of torture or cruel treatment upon return to Pakistan
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Selective interpretation of evidence by delegate
Crimes.Application_Error: Failure to adequately justify conclusions based on evidence
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Widespread reports of torture in Pakistan, personal risk factors
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Personal risk of torture or cruel and unusual treatment under Section 97
Crimes.Application_Factor: Inclusion on CBSA wanted list

Crimes.Application_Facts: Pakistani citizen overstayed visa, claimed protection in Canada, refugee claim denied
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Procedural fairness and independence of decision-maker
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Jurisdiction of Minister's Delegate under IRPA
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Documentary evidence on country conditions in Pakistan
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failure to link generalized risk to personal risk
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant’s risk deemed generalized rather than personal
Crimes.Outcome: Judicial review granted, decision set aside, remitted for redetermination
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Personal risk of torture under Section 97 of IRPA
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Selective interpretation of evidence, unsupported conclusions

Crimes.Crime_Name: Work Permit Refusal under Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the Minister's Delegate reasonably concluded that the Applicant would not face a risk if returned to Pakistan
Crimes.Outcome: Judicial review granted, decision set aside, remitted for reassessment
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant linked to terrorism, faces significant risk upon return
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence on torture in Pakistani detention centers
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Risk of torture due to alleged terrorism links
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Selective interpretation of evidence by delegate
Crimes.Application_Error: Inconsistent findings and failure to consider relevant evidence
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Widespread reports of torture in detention centers
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Personal risk of torture or cruel treatment under Section 97
Crimes.Application_Factor: Alleged terrorism affiliation increasing risk profile
